content: c4 worsted c5 worsted c6 fingering c7 fuzzy fingering all in portions of 34 yards each or mix it up the way you want to the thinner the yarn is the more lacy the cowl will be thicker yarns will produce a more dense and tighter cowl the extra mini skein talked about in the yarn section is a sport weight and should contrast the last color in your cowl to do the contrasting stretchy bind off with part 1 getting started adding stripes with size 7 needle and c1- co 74 sts pl m and whether you stay with the smaller size or opt join in the round being careful not to twist sts to increase for more width more yarn needed knit 7 rounds simply knit every row until you have 6 color changes completed and used up c1 2 3 4 5 6 part 2 increase by changing needle size with c7 - knit every row leaving enough yarn left over and attached approximately 3 times with c1 and size 10 5 needle knit about 7 more the circumference of your cowl so far to work rounds the stretchy bind off as described next with c2 knit another 7 rounds part 3 eyelet increases stretchy bind off with c3 k2 yo repeat to last 2 sts k2 109 sts with c7 yarn still attached and two strands of c8 held double with 3 strands held together continue to knit approximately 6 more rounds before next color change k2 pl both sts back on lhn and ktog tbl continue to k1 pl both sts back on lhn and ktog tbl repeat to last st optional this is a good place to see if you need more circumference/width cut yarn feed end through last loop and pull tight place your stitches on hold on scrap yarn about 2 5 yards in length to be safe and try it on finishing you can now decide whether to increase your needle size to a us 13 9 mm or add another weave in all ends blocking is optional this eyelet increase round with a more dramatic sample was left unblocked for a more organic increase look keep in mind blocking can make your cowl larger optional increase round k5 yo repeat to last4 st k4 131 sts more yarn is needed enjoy your comfort cowl web www yarnz2go com email yarnz2go@gmail com ravelry petrabreakstone © petra breakstone for personal use page 2 of 2
